claim.text: Nordic cities — Oulu, Finland; Tromsø, Norway; Luleå, Sweden — have demonstrated that winter cities can be vibrant twelve months a year
claim.claim: Oulu (Finland), Tromsø (Norway), and Luleå (Sweden) have implemented winter city design strategies that maintain year-round urban vibrancy

claim.text: The design moves: heated sidewalks at key intersections, wind-breaking building placement, south-facing building faces along pedestrian routes, covered walkways at transit stops, and snow storage designed into the streetscape
claim.claim: Nordic cities (Oulu, Tromsø, Luleå) use these specific design features: heated sidewalks at intersections, wind-breaking building placement, south-facing pedestrian routes, covered transit stop walkways, and integrated snow storage

results.summary: Nordic cities do employ various winter-friendly design features, but the specific claim aggregates practices that may not all exist in each named city.
results.detail: Oulu, Finland is indeed known as a 'winter cycling city' and uses some winter-adapted infrastructure. Nordic cities generally do incorporate wind protection in building placement, snow storage planning, and transit shelter design. However, heated sidewalks are expensive and typically limited to specific high-traffic areas (like central squares) rather than 'key intersections' broadly. Without web access to verify current implementations in Tromsø and Luleå specifically, I cannot confirm all five design features are present across all three cities as claimed.
